description.heading: What is HTTP?
bullet-points: HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol) is the foundation of communication on the World Wide Web.
It establishes rules for how data travels between browsers and web servers.
Imagine HTTP like a bank withdrawal form that you use to withdraw (request) cash (response) from the banker (server).

description.heading: How HTTP works?
bullet-points: A client (browser) initiates a request by specifying an address (URL) and an action (GET, POST, etc.).
The server receives the request, processes it, and sends a response with data or an error message.
This back-and-forth exchange allows web pages, images, and other content to be delivered to your browser.

description.heading: Key features of HTTP:
bullet-points: Request-response cycle — Ensures organized communication between browsers and servers.
Stateless protocol — Each request is treated independently, promoting scalability.
Flexible methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) — Define different actions on web resources.
Supports various content types — Enables transfer of text, images, videos, and more.

description.heading: Beyond the basics:
bullet-points: HTTP is the foundation for many web protocols like HTTPS (secure HTTP) and REST (architectural style).
Understanding HTTP is essential for building and interacting with web applications.
